title: Life Cycle Stage of Monarch Butterfly

questions.questionText: What do you notice about the caterpillar's colors and patterns?

rubric.exceeds: Student identifies three or more specific colors (yellow, black, white) and describes the stripe pattern with detail, such as noting how the stripes go across the caterpillar's body.
rubric.meets: Student correctly names at least two colors of the caterpillar and mentions that it has stripes or a pattern.
rubric.approaching: Student names one color or mentions stripes, but lacks detail or accuracy in describing the pattern.
rubric.beginning: Student makes a simple observation about how the caterpillar looks, such as saying it is colorful or has lines, with minimal specific details.

questions.questionText: Why do you think the caterpillar needs to shed its skin?

rubric.exceeds: Student explains that caterpillars shed their skin because they grow bigger and their old skin becomes too tight, and may connect this to the empty shell shown in the photo.
rubric.meets: Student provides a reasonable explanation that the caterpillar sheds its skin because it grows or because the skin gets too small.
rubric.approaching: Student attempts an explanation related to growth or changing, but the reasoning is unclear or incomplete.
rubric.beginning: Student provides a vague response such as the caterpillar sheds its skin to clean itself, or gives little to no explanation.

questions.questionText: How is this caterpillar similar to and different from the butterfly it will become?

rubric.exceeds: Student identifies multiple similarities (both have stripes/colors, both are insects, both have bodies) and differences (caterpillar crawls/eats plants vs. butterfly flies/drinks nectar, different body shape), showing understanding of life cycle changes.
rubric.meets: Student correctly identifies at least one similarity and one difference between the caterpillar and butterfly, such as noting they look different or move differently.
rubric.approaching: Student identifies either a similarity or a difference, but not both, or the response contains one inaccurate comparison.
rubric.beginning: Student provides a minimal or unclear response that does not clearly compare the caterpillar and butterfly.

questions.questionText: What would happen if caterpillars couldn't shed their skin as they grew?

rubric.exceeds: Student explains that the caterpillar would not be able to grow properly, might get stuck or uncomfortable, and would not be able to become a butterfly, showing understanding of how shedding supports growth and development.
rubric.meets: Student provides a reasonable prediction that the caterpillar would have trouble growing or would not be able to get bigger.
rubric.approaching: Student attempts a prediction but with incomplete reasoning, such as saying something bad would happen without explaining why.
rubric.beginning: Student provides a vague response such as the caterpillar would be sad, or offers a prediction with little connection to the skin-shedding concept.
